commands.name: Step 1: Create Namespace
commands.command: kubectl create namespace scenarios --dry-run=client -o yaml | kubectl apply -f -
commands.next_step: Deploy application with health probes configured.

commands.name: Step 2: Deploy Application with Probes
commands.description: Deploy app with liveness and readiness probes
commands.explanation: Creates deployment with both probe types configured. Liveness probe checks /healthz every 3s after 3s delay. Readiness probe checks /healthz every 5s after 5s delay. This deployment uses k8s.gcr.io/liveness image which simulates probe failures.
commands.what_it_does: Creates deployment 'probes-demo' and service with 2 replicas.
commands.next_step: Check pods are running with probes active.

commands.name: Step 3: Verify Pods Running
commands.explanation: Should see 2 pods in Running state. Both probes must pass for pods to be Running and Ready.

commands.name: Step 4: Describe Pod Probes
commands.command: kubectl describe pod -n scenarios -l app=probes-demo | grep -A 5 'Liveness\|Readiness'
commands.explanation: Shows liveness and readiness probe configurations including paths, delays, periods, and thresholds.
commands.what_it_does: Displays probe configurations from pod spec.

commands.name: Step 5: Watch Probe Events
commands.command: kubectl get events -n scenarios --field-selector involvedObject.kind=Pod --sort-by='.lastTimestamp' | tail -20
commands.description: See recent pod events including probe results
commands.explanation: Look for 'Liveness probe failed' or 'Readiness probe failed' events. Initially all should be passing.
commands.what_it_does: Lists recent pod events sorted by time.

commands.name: Step 6: Simulate Liveness Failure
commands.description: Remove health file to fail liveness probe
commands.explanation: The liveness probe checks for /tmp/healthy file. Removing it causes the probe to fail. After 3 failures (failureThreshold: 3), Kubernetes restarts the container.
commands.what_it_does: Triggers liveness probe failure by removing health indicator.
commands.next_step: Watch pod restart due to liveness failure.

commands.name: Step 7: Watch Pod Restart
commands.description: Monitor pod restart from liveness failure
commands.explanation: You'll see RESTARTS count increment and pod briefly show NotReady. Liveness failure triggers container restart (not pod deletion). Press Ctrl+C after seeing restart.
commands.what_it_does: Streams live pod status showing restart.

commands.name: Step 8: Check Restart Count
commands.explanation: RESTARTS column shows how many times containers have been restarted. Should be 1 or more after liveness failure. This proves liveness probe auto-recovery.

commands.name: Step 9: Check Service Endpoints
commands.explanation: Shows which pod IPs are included in the service. Only Ready pods are listed. If a pod fails readiness, it's removed from here (but pod stays running).
commands.what_it_does: Lists pod IPs receiving traffic from service.
commands.next_step: Scenario complete! Probes protect service availability.

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete Resources
commands.explanation: Deletes all resources created in this scenario.
